sized” lump which the officer knew from his training and experience to be crack cocaine.\
At that time, the officer pulled down Marshall’s pants and underwear. He observed, from behind,\
a baggie tucked in Marshall’s genitals containing narcotics. Without touching Marshall’s\
anatomy, the officer removed the narcotics.\
ISSUE 1:

title: Did probable cause exist to search Marshall’s groin beyond a Terry frisk?
content:
HOLDING:\
\
Yes.\
\
DISCUSSION: When the officer felt what he knew to be crack-cocaine during the lawful Terry\
frisk, the officer had probable cause pursuant to the plain-feel doctrine to conduct a further\
search. Once he established the lump to be crack cocaine, the officer had probable cause to\
arrest Marshall for possession of crack cocaine. Therefore, a further search was justified as\
incident to a lawful arrest. The Court explained, “the reasonable search of an individual should\
not be held unconstitutional simply because the suspect chooses to hide contraband in a\
85\
\
 potentially embarrassing location and does so in a manner that makes the contraband\
immediately apparent to the plain feel of an officer\'s open hand.”114\
ISSUE 2:

title: Was the strip search reasonable?
content:
HOLDING:\
\
Yes.\
\
DISCUSSION: To begin, the Court recognized there is no bright-line rule about how invasive a\
warrantless search may be. However, a valid arrest does not mean that an arrestee is subject to\
any and all searches an arresting officer wishes to conduct. It depends on the circumstances.\
Therefore, even a search supported by probable cause maybe be unconstitutional if it is\
conducted in an unreasonable manner. Strip-searches are inherently invasive and embarrassing,\
so it is of great importance that they be conducted reasonably.\
To determine whether a strip search is reasonable, the court will consider four factors. The\
second factor is further broken down into four parts:115\
(1) the scope of the particular intrusion,\
(2) the manner in which the search is conducted:\
a. the type of search and its commonality,\
b. who performed the search,\
c. the weighted risk, pain, and trauma to the arrestee, and\
d. the skills required to conduct the search.\
(3) the justification for initiating the search, and\
(4) the place in which it is conducted.\
Considering these factors, the Court concluded the strip search was reasonable. First, the scope\
of the intrusion was merely a visual inspection. Second, strip searches are a commonly\
performed search by law enforcement officers. And while it was embarrassing for Marshall, it\
was conducted within four walls, out of sight of any other persons, and no one physically\
touched any sensitive anatomy. Any pain, trauma, or risk was minimal. Further, there is not\
specialized training required to conduct a strip search. It requires only common sense and\
decency which was displayed here by the officers. Third, this search was supported by probable\
cause. Fourth, the search was conducted within four walls, and Marshall was not exposed to\
anyone not involved in the search.\
Therefore, based on the totality of the circumstances, the strip search was reasonable.\
\

\

title: On April 22, 1987, Corporal Davis of the Montgomery (Alabama) Police
content:
Department received a phone call from an unknown person, who stated that Vanessa White\
would be leaving a particular address at a particular time in a specifically described vehicle. The\
caller further stated that she would be going to Dobey’s Motel and would be in possession of\
approximately an ounce of cocaine inside a briefcase. Davis proceeded to the address given,\
along with another officer, and watched White leave the building and get into the vehicle. Davis\
then followed White to the motel. At that time, White appeared to be carrying nothing. With the\
help of a marked unit, Davis stopped the vehicle and asked White to step out, which she did.\
Davis explained that she was suspected of carrying cocaine, and requested permission to search,\
which she gave. Davis found a briefcase in the trunk, and White provided the combination. Davis\
found marijuana in the briefcase and arrested White. During booking, a small amount of cocaine\
was found in White’s purse.\
White moved to suppress the evidence based on an unlawful stop, but the motion was denied.

title: Can a sufficiently detailed and corroborated anonymous tip support a vehicle
content:
HOLDING:\
\
Yes.\
\
DISCUSSION: The Court compared this situation to Illinois v. Gates, stating that the standard for\
a vehicle stop was lower than that required for a search warrant: reasonable suspicion versus\
probable cause. Following the logic in Gates, the Court stated that “Gates gave credit to the\
proposition that because an informant is shown to be right about some things, he is probably\
right about other facts that he has alleged, including the claim that the object of the tip is\
engaged in criminal activity.” The “independent corroboration by the police of significant aspects\
of the informer’s predictions imparted some degree of reliability to the other allegations made\
by the caller.” The Court also took note that the tip not only included details of currently existing\
conditions, but also predicted the object’s future actions, demonstrating “inside information – a\
special familiarity with [White’s] affairs.

title: Miami-Dade officers received an anonymous tip that a young black male was
content:
standing at a particular bus stop, wearing a plaid shirt, and that he was in possession of a gun. A\
few minutes later, officers found J.L., wearing a plaid shirt, along with two other young men,\
standing at that location. The officers observed no suspicious conduct, nor did they see anything\
to lead them to suspect that J.L. had a weapon. They seized and frisked J.L. and found a firearm.\
87\
\
 Ultimately, the Florida courts found that the search was invalid and suppressed the evidence.

title: Can an anonymous tip alone, with no other corroborating information, give
content:
reasonable suspicion to frisk for a gun?\
HOLDING:\
\
No.\
\
DISCUSSION: The Court held that an anonymous tip that is unsupported by specific information\
about a firearm is not sufficient to satisfy the requirement of Terry that an officer have\
reasonable suspicion before initiating a search. In this case, the officers had nothing but an\
anonymous tip about an individual carrying a firearm. An exception strictly because a firearm is\
alleged would subject individuals to the potential for harassment by officers acting solely on\
anonymous tips that may, or may not, be credible. The Court insists on at least an indicia of\
reliability and credibility in anonymous tips. The Court specifically stated that this case does not\
reach to areas where an individual has a diminished expectation of privacy, such as airports and\
schools.

 resist or effect his escape. In addition, the officer can search for and seize any evidence on the\
